page.para: Grandma loves telling stories. The children love to listen. “We’re ready, grandma,” said Deeksha.
“Once upon a time, there was a girl called Divya,” said grandma. “She lived in a hut beside the forest.”
“Divya had a beautiful voice. She sang as she worked. Even the birds liked to listen!”
“One morning, while Divya was singing, a monster appeared! He had thick fur, and long arms, and red eyes.”
“ ‘Come with me, little girl,’ said the monster. He snatched Divya up, and ran off into the forest.”
“Divya kicked. She screamed. She shouted. But nobody heard. Deep into the forest they went.”
“Eventually they arrived at the monster’s cave. The monster pushed Divya into a cage.”
“ ‘I can’t sleep. So you must sing to me, little girl,’ said the monster.”
“Meanwhile, Divya’s brother Krishna was looking for her. ‘Divya! Divya!’ he called. Then he saw big footprints. Oh no!”
“Krishna followed the footprints. Deep into the forest he went. And then he heard beautiful singing. It was Divya!”
“Krishna crept to the cave. He saw Divya in the cage. He saw the monster, fast asleep.”
“Quietly, Krishna unbolted the cage door. Then the children tiptoed away.”
“Out in the forest, it was getting dark. The children were scared. They ran and ran and ran towards home.”
“Mum was at the door, waiting for them. They ran to her.”
“But suddenly, they heard loud wailing from the forest. ‘Oh no,’ said Divya. ‘The monster is crying!’ ”
“What happened next, grandma?” asked Aditya. But there was no answer. Grandma had fallen asleep.
